videos.title: Audio Fairy Tales - The Wolf and the Seven Little Kids - Age 7 to 12 - Storyberries.com
videos.description:
SUBSCRIBE - https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCQoz7oLrUVZlC0hsXdyA7oA/?sub_confirmation=1

ORIGINAL STORY - https://www.storyberries.com/fairy-tales-the-wolf-and-the-seven-little-kids-by-brothers-grimm/

A mother goat leaves her seven little kids at home alone... but are they smart enough to outwit a wolf?

This is a classic fairy tale by the Brothers Grimm. You can read this story for free online at Storyberries.com. Read along at  https://www.storyberries.com/fairy-tales-the-wolf-and-the-seven-little-kids-by-brothers-grimm/

----
Let’s Chat About The Stories ~ Ideas for Talking With Kids

Love, Family

1. The story says that the mother goat loved her children "with all the love of a mother for her children". What do you think is special about a mother's love for her children? How does the mother goat show her love for her kids in this story?

2. How did the family co-operate in saving the baby goats who had been swallowed by the wolf? What do you think a story like this shows about a family who works together as a team?

----
Fairy Tales by Brothers Grimm
Read by Jade Maitre - https://www.storyberries.com/author/jade-maitre/

Storyberries presents "The Little Peach Who Spoke Italian", the story of a little boy who falls in love with a peach stone, which he carries around Italy on vacation.
----
🍓Let’s Chat About The Stories  🍓 Ideas for Talking With Kids 🍓

Love
1. Have you ever loved someone or something very much? What kinds of things did you do for the thing or person you loved? How did it make you feel?

Healthy Eating
1. Italy is a country known for its love of good food. What does 'good food' mean to you?

videos.title: AUDIO - Chuchu Manthu's Jar of Toffees - Story for kids about love, dying and loss| Storyberries.com
videos.description:
READ ALONG: https://www.storyberries.com/bedtime-stories-chuchu-manchus-jar-of-toffees/

Description: Chuchu Manchu's Jar of Toffees. Preet loves Chuchu Manthu… but one day he is gone. How can she remember him with love?

Subscribe for more stories for kids to go to sleep: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCQoz7oLrUVZlC0hsXdyA7oA/?sub_confirmation=1
----
🍓Let’s Chat About The Stories  🍓 Ideas for Talking With Kids 🍓
Dying and Loss

1. Why do you think Preet feels happy when she throws the toffees out of the window like Chuchu Manthu used to do?

2. Can you think of other ways that people might remember the people they love who have died?

Love

1. Why does Preet love about Chuchu Manchu?

2. How does Chuchu Manthu show his love for others?

3. Do you think it is good to be remembered in a loving way when someone is not here any more? Why or why not?

----

2. What do you think is worth loving about yourself?

3. What do you think is the most important thing to love in ourselves and others? Why?

4. Do you think that love comes in all different shapes and sizes? What might this say about love?

----

2. Can you think of some reasons why your own home is the perfect place for you?

videos.title: Under My Bed - Story for kids about fearfulness (Animated Bedtime Story) | Storyberries.com
videos.description:
🍓 SUBSCRIBE at https://storyberries.myflodesk.com/sign-up 🍓 
Description:  The child in this story is very frightened that there is a tiger under the bed. ... When Mum pulled out the jacket from under the bed, the child in this story realised that their fears had been unfounded.

Original story: https://www.storyberries.com/bedtime-stories-under-my-bed-short-stories-for-kids-about-going-to-bed/

Subscribe for more stories for kids to go to sleep: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCQoz7oLrUVZlC0hsXdyA7oA/?sub_confirmation=1
----
🍓Let’s Chat About The Stories  🍓 Ideas for Talking With Kids 🍓

Fearfulness

1. The child in this story is very frightened that there is a tiger under the bed. Even before you got to the end of the story, did you think it was very likely that there was a tiger under the bed?

2. If you thought it was not very likely, why do you think the child still believed there might be one there?

3. When Mum pulled out the jacket from under the bed, the child in this story realised that their fears had been unfounded. What do you think this might tell us about many of the things that frighten us?

----

videos.title: People Who Help - Story for kids about helping & independent thinking (Animated Bedtime Story)
videos.description:
🍓 SUBSCRIBE at https://storyberries.myflodesk.com/sign-up 🍓 

People Who Help - Story for kids about helping & independent thinking (Animated Bedtime Story)  | Storyberries.com

Description: A poem of appreciation for all the nurses, doctors, paramedics, firefighters, policeman and others who help in their jobs. 

This story was written by our beloved regular contributor Phoebe Coghlan, who also works as an Intensive Care Nurse working in a Central London hospital. During these trying times, we celebrate our key workers who are on the front line keeping us safe, but Phoebe also wishes to remember those who are vulnerable across the world during this coronavirus pandemic.

Original story: https://www.storyberries.com/short-stories-for-kids-people-who-help-free-books-online/

Subscribe for more stories for kids to go to sleep: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCQoz7oLrUVZlC0hsXdyA7oA/?sub_confirmation=1
----
🍓Let’s Chat About The Stories  🍓 Ideas for Talking With Kids 🍓

Helping, Independent Thinking

1. Why do you think it's good for people to help each other in our world?

2. What do you think the world would look like if we didn't help each other?

3. Sometimes people help others, even if they risk hurting themselves or getting sick. Why do you think some people help, even if it might harm them?

4. Can you think of some other jobs where people help others?

Conversation

1. What kind of job would you like to do when you grow up?

----

Music Video: Doobly Doo Kevin MacLeod (incompetech.com), "Balloon Game" Kevin MacLeod (incompetech.com), "Doobly Doo" Kevin MacLeod (incompetech.com), Licensed under Creative Commons: By Attribution 4.0 License, http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/ 

Author bio
Renée Jackson is a retired university lecturer in mathematics education – with a focus on wonderment, mystery and surprise. She holds a Master of Education from the University of Alberta and has more than thirty years of teaching experience. A great deal of her teaching philosophy is currently informed by spending time with her delightful grandchildren.

Illustrator bio
Sarah Jackson is a Canadian illustrator, designer, and concoctor of the A Jam Story children’s book series (ajamstory.com). She likes creating things for real people (not robots). She also enjoys salsa dancing, jumping around her studio and cat naps.

Credits:

Author Illustrator: © Macarena Smerdou 2020
About the Author Illustrator (Translated from Spanish:):

"I really like to draw, especially children's illustrations. When I found I was not getting enough story commissions, I decided to write my own stories. The first two "Carlota Doesn't Like Yellow "and" Carlota's Move" were published in 2005 by the Editorial Biblioteca Nueva. From there I have collaborated as an illustrator with several publishers, authors and magazines, but I have also continued to invent stories.

In 2009 I published, together with the author-illustrator Elena Dams “The Collection of Children's Rights”, ten stories to explain to little ones their rights and those of other children. In 2014 I started my website www.macasmerdou.es dedicated to the design and illustration of personalized products. In 2016 I collaborated as an illustrator in the collection of short stories, "Los Secrets and Adventures of Posi," by Cristina Ozores, edited by the Vellmarí association, with the collaboration of the Environment and Culture of the Consell Insular de Formentera, an educational project for the dissemination among the youngest of the importance of grasslands of oceanic posidonia in the marine ecosystem of the Mediterranean Sea.

Story therapy is my latest project. It consists of the creation of stories on request, for children who may have a problem, who may need assistance overcoming the circumstances of their life, or who simply want to be protagonists of their own story. I have recently launched my blog where you can see all the stories that I am doing for very special boys and girls. 

You can follow me here: www.cuentoterapia-macasmerdou.blogspot.es "

Steve Tubbs is a lawyer by trade, whose annual holiday letters tickle the ribs of those on his list. Pembral Forgets invokes the hallmarks of fall, with colorful leaves and frost on the ground, and, of course, the wonderful aroma of baking in the kitchen. It is Steve's first effort as an author.

After spending 14 years in the hospitality industry, I was afforded the special opportunity to stay home with my two beautiful young sons to help focus on their schooling and development. During this time, I was delighted and privileged to also rediscover my love for the arts. I have been taking the opportunity to refine my skill set, learn some new skills and pick up on current technology which serves the artistic community. Few people ever have the privilege of making their passion their pursuit as well and making a career of it, but I am finally in a position to attempt to do just that. With the support of my family, I am enjoying every moment I spend creating my treasured illustrations and showing my sons what is possible when passion meets perseverance.

You can follow Nicola's work at her Instagram account @nicolaanneillustrates

Polly Humphrey and her dad wrote and illustrated their first children’s book, TEDDY BEAR PIRATE, based on stories they would make up before bedtime. In her book, all the crew of the HMS Seashell are all based on Polly’s favourite toys and she enjoys imagining their individual characters as they sail the seas.

About the Author Illustrator:

Sue Clancy, an American artist, author, and illustrator who lives in Washington state is known for her whimsical, timeless, comforting, quirky and oddly cute art images and artist books often featuring animals. Though she is the author/artist for more than 6 books and numerous fine art exhibits she is still very carefully supervised in her art studio by a miniature longhaired dachshund and a tabby cat. Clancy loves to read, cook and play with words and pictures. You can see more about Clancy's art here: www.sueclancy.com

🍓Let’s Chat About The Stories  🍓 Ideas for Talking With Kids 🍓

Self-Confidence

1. Kathy loves sheep herding and does not want to be a Princess. Why do you think people might want to be a Princess? Why might they not want to be a Princess?

2. Kathy makes the right decision for her. How can you tell, from reading the book, that she made the right decision?

Beauty

1. Do you think Princesses have to be "beautiful"? What does "beautiful" mean, in this story?

2. At the end of the story, all the girls and women in the kingdom are given Princess crowns. Do you think this means that all the girls and women were "beautiful"? How?

🍓 DESCRIPTION: Dissledoo - One year, while practicing his gift-delivering route, Santa gets stuck in Australia! Luckily, some friendly native animals help him, along with a magical car called Dissledoo. But when Santa returns to do his deliveries on Christmas Eve, he soon discovers that it’s much easier to deliver presents to all the children of the world with friends by his side! Dissledoo is a bright and happy Christmas tale about the power of friendship. It’s also the perfect book for explaining to young children about seasons, co-operation, and the magic of Christmas.

Empathy, Kindness

Independent Thinking

1. Do you think it is always a good idea to trust wild animals? Why or why not?

2. Why was Breeze not frightened of this particular bear?

3. Do you think she took enough care for her safety when she approached the bear? Why or why not?

1. This is a retelling of a very famous fairy tale, The Pied Piper of Hamelin. Fairy tales often have a message to help us understand life. What do you think might be the message in this story?

2. Do you think it was fair for the piper to take the children from Hamelin? Why or why not?

3. The villagers decided not to pay the piper when he rid their town of the rats. What might this story also tell us about being honest with others?

🍓Let’s Chat About The Stories  🍓 Ideas for Talking With Kids 🍓

Independent Thinking, Feelings, Independence, Mindfulness

1. In this story, Tashi is angry and lashes out at the spider. But then he discovers that he has chalk on himself! What do you think this might say about what can happen if we attack others when we are feeling angry?

2. When we read stories sometimes, things in the stories can be a symbol for something else. In this story, what do you think the rainbow chalk might be a symbol of?

3. Tashi believes he is a brave and courageous warrior. Why do you think Tashi wanted to prove himself brave and strong? Who do you think he needed to prove this to?

4. At first, Tashi thinks it is important to be powerful and angry to be a warrior. What does he learn might be more important qualities to being a good warrior?

Warning: The following is a 'Once Untold' fairy tale. It may contain elements that are scary for younger or sensitive readers. Please do not watch if you are sensitive to such stories.

----
🍓Let’s Chat About The Stories  🍓 Ideas for Talking With Kids 🍓

Courage

1. Who were brave in this story? When were they brave?

2. Do you think they could be brave if they were scared? Does being brave mean that you can't be scared at the same time?

Fairness

1. Who was unfair in this story? Why do you think each of them was unfair? To whom?

2. What good things do you think come from people being fair to one another?

Honor

1. Why do you think Little Pea cared so much for his family?

2. What do you think is 'honor'?
